This will link back to the [[first concept]] and to the [[second concept]]

In person-to-person systems, how the [[feedback]] is received is dependent on the receiver of the feedback and the giver of the feedback. Feedback that is too blunt or too radical from the receiver's worldview may be met with anger or denial. Feedback that is too soft may not have a large enough impact to cause change.

Feedback loops are not the same as cycles like vicious cycles or virtuous cycles; the primary difference is that a feedback loop returns results to the instigator, whereas cycles may have intermediate steps. Feedback loops and [[feedback]] in general also are more associated with immediacy than cycles.

Continuous improvement is more related to [[motivation]] than it is [[feedback]]. People have access to many [[feedback loops]] in their day-to-day lives, so the difference between those who use that feedback to get better and those who ignore it is [[motivation]] to get better. In other words, if someone does not want to practice continuous improvement, no amount of feedback will help, although feedback may sometimes be the motivation when people are extrinsically motivated or motivated by recognition.

Continuous improvement is a [[mindset]] that drives an individual or team to better themselves every day.

Continuous improvement relies on [[feedback loops]] to identify areas that can be improved. The feedback loops can be internally-driven by [[self awareness]] or external from social influences of events that produce undesired results

Agile is a mindset that reinforces the key principles of [[customer focus]], [[continuous improvement]], empowered people, delivery of value
Agile is a mindset that reinforces the key principles of [[customer focus]], [[continuous improvement]], empowered people, delivery of value
Customer focus is the concept that everything done in business should be done to add value to the [[customer]]
A factor of safety is a form of [[buffer]] for a system.
